author: albusdompeldorius
content: I was just arguing about the possibility that some censored transactions never will be included. I don't think that will happen if enough validators are rational (not even altruistic).

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if we consider the `builder ‚¨ÜÔ∏è => private transaction RPC ‚¨ÜÔ∏è => builder ‚¨ÜÔ∏è` vicious cycle?

author: albusdompeldorius
content: Yes, because the value of the censored transactions will only increase, while the value of the highest-value censoring block will not. When the total value of the censored transactions are higher than the highest-value censoring block, a rational validator will include them.

author: sky.cactus
content:
It would be interesting to see a 3D graph with axis:
Number of non-censoring validators.
Total censored gas per 60 days.
Priority fee overpayment required for inclusion.

author: sky.cactus
content: While you are technically correct that if the censored users are willing to pay *enough* they may be able to overcome the aforementioned vicious cycle, but I *personally* would consider someone who has to pay significantly more than everyone else to be functionally "censored".

author: sky.cactus
content: e.g., if the cost of inclusion is 100x for a censored transaction, then I would argue the transaction is functionally censored.

author: sky.cactus
content: When total censoring gas per 60 days exceeds number of non-censoring validators * 30,000,000 the overpayment required for inclusion will go to infinity, so not particularly interesting there, but I think the rest of the chart could be illustrative.

author: sky.cactus
content: You would need to assume censoring blocks have access to a larger transaction pool than non-censoring blocks though, and by how much is another variable and 4D charts are hard.  üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content: We can imagine a future where the public mempool *only* has censored transactions in it and all non-censored transactions go through private pools.  In this scenario, the total fee reward of all currently mineable censored transactions needs to exceed the fee reward of a normally filled censored block.

author: sky.cactus
content: Interestingly, in this hypothetical we have "solved" the MEV problem via a 100% trusted centralized intermediary.  üòÜ

author: albusdompeldorius
content: You do get the advantage that you can fill the block up to the limit though.

author: sky.cactus
content: Yeah, censored transactions will have to sit until their total fee yield is greater than a normal block's fee yield, and this can be up to 30M gas worth of such censored transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Depending on user preference, it may be that the priority fee increases faster than the transactions "back up", or it could be that censored users end up waiting for longer and eventually you have > 15M gas worth of fees and a profit-seeking validator with multiple relays configured will produce a block with censored transactions in it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not a huge fan designs with this many variables in play, especially with so many human unknows.
